title: Particle Motion with Eulers Method and Taylor Poly

content.question:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.
Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.
Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.
Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

<math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with three columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in minutes.” The heading for row 2 is “x prime of t, in feet per minute.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. x prime of t is 7.0. Column 2. t is 3. x prime of t is 6.2. Column 3. t is 6. x prime of t is 8.0." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" equalcolumns="false" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowalign="center" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(minutes)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(feet per minute)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>7.0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6.2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8.0</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>

The position of a particle moving along a straight line is modeled by a twice-differentiable function <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in minutes and <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in feet. Selected values of <math alttext="x prime of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, the derivative of <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, are shown in the table above. The position of the particle at time <math alttext="t equals 6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="x of 6 equals 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Approximate <math alttext="x double prime of 4.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> using the average rate of change of <math alttext="x prime of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="3 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

frqParts.text:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.
Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.
Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.
Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

<math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with three columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in minutes.” The heading for row 2 is “x prime of t, in feet per minute.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. x prime of t is 7.0. Column 2. t is 3. x prime of t is 6.2. Column 3. t is 6. x prime of t is 8.0." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" equalcolumns="false" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowalign="center" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(minutes)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(feet per minute)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>7.0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6.2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8.0</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>

The position of a particle moving along a straight line is modeled by a twice-differentiable function <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in minutes and <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in feet. Selected values of <math alttext="x prime of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, the derivative of <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, are shown in the table above. The position of the particle at time <math alttext="t equals 6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="x of 6 equals 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Approximate <math alttext="x double prime of 4.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> using the average rate of change of <math alttext="x prime of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="3 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(b) Using correct units, explain the meaning of <math alttext="x double prime of 4.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem.

(c) Use a left Riemann sum with the two subintervals indicated by the data in the table to approximate <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 6, of, the absolute value of x prime of t, end absolute value, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mrow><mo>|</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(d) Using correct units, explain the meaning of <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 6, of, the absolute value of x prime of t, end absolute value, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mrow><mo>|</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem.

(e) Use Euler’s method, starting at <math alttext="t equals 6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> with two steps of equal size, to approximate the position of the particle at time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(f) Let <math alttext="s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be a function such that the third derivative of <math alttext="s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> with respect to <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="open parenthesis, t plus 5, close parenthesis, raised to the sixth power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Write the fourth-degree term of the fourth-degree Taylor polynomial for <math alttext="s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> about <math alttext="t equals negative 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 4.2: Straight-Line Motion - Connecting Position, Velocity, and Acceleration

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
